results.title: Introduction to Orchestra!: Upper strings. Woodwind
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Hewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Orchestra!”.
This volume of the “Orchestra!” series provides an introduction to the methods and objectives of the series. It also examines the role of the the upper string instruments, violin and viola and the early work of Bach and Handel. It also examines the woodwind section focussing on the oboe and the use of a double reed.

results.title: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit: Don Levy, James Archibald and British Information Services
results.brief_description: An impressionistic survey of the arts in Britain ranging from sculptors and painters at work to a display of Mary Quant fashions and vistas of modern architecture. The theatre is represented by excerpts from three plays staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company and there is a sequence from a new ballet by Sir Frederick Ashton. Some of the work of Henry Moore is seen as well as paintings by Francis Bacon. Includes a brief appearance by a very young Googie Withers.

results.title: Options
results.creator_credit: Howard Sturges, Jerry Aronson and Perspective Films
results.brief_description: Believing that people want to feel, hear and become involved in art, the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art, and its sister museums created “Options” - an exhibit meant to be touched and played with. It is a new approach to contemporary museums, involving more than just passive looking. The roving camera explores the reactions of the participants, and through the use of fast cuts, unusual angles and electronic music, the film becomes as involving an experience as the exhibit itself. Narrated by Ken Nordine.

results.title: Dartmouth
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Dartmouth Dam, on the Mitta Mitta River in Victoria, has been designed to manage the waters of the River Murray for irrigation and urban needs. This film tells the story of the making of Dartmouth Dam including the study of plant and animal life. Reminiscences about the old Dartmouth township, and plans for the new town of Dartmouth. Narrated by Simon Chilvers.

results.title: Darling Darling
results.creator_credit: Sam Smith, Bridget Ikin and Gabriella Hirst
results.credit_line:
Gabriella Hirst
Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound, 25:30 mins.
SanDisk Memory Card, gold leaf, in collaboration with Barbara Dabrowa, AGNSW Senior Conservator of Fine Arts – Frames
Courtesy the artist
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound and gilded SD card
results.brief_description:
Darling Darling presents two contrasting but linked responses to the idea of conservation. One side of the screen shows the meticulous care taken to restore WC Piguenit’s prized 1895 painting of the Barka-Darling River, The flood in the Darling, 1890, while the other side reveals the present-day neglect of the river itself. Excess upstream water diversion and climate change have contributed to severe water scarcity and mass fish kills in recent years.

In composing her shots of the river, Hirst references Australia’s beloved landscape painting tradition, and colonial-era artists like Eugene von Guérard, John Glover, Conrad Martens, Nicholas Chevalier, Ludwig Becker and of course, WC Piguenit. While their romantic paintings capture a sense of nature as awe inspiring, they also served the more material purpose of framing resources to be owned and exploited by European settlers, a visual expression of the concept of terra nullius.

Darling Darling invites us to question the role played by Western visual art traditions in shaping the value systems that allow such an extreme environmental crisis to unfold right before our eyes.

Gabriella Hirst (she/her) is an artist. She was born and grew up on Cammeraygal land (Australia) and is currently living between Berlin and London. She works primarily with moving image, performance, and with the garden as a site of critique and care. Gabriella’s practice and research explores connections between various manifestations of capture and control – spanning plant taxonomies, landscape painting, art conservation and nuclear history.

results.title: Darwin's body snatchers
results.creator_credit: Chris Oxley, Channel 4, U K and Laurel Productions
results.brief_description: This program looks at the export trade in Aboriginal skeletons, skulls and body parts rife during the nineteenth century and which continued up until 1940. Anthropologists and museums influenced by the work of Charles Darwin sought these remains for scientific study and museum exhibition. Australian doctors, scientists and supposedly respectable citizens may have colluded in both grave robbing and “killing to order”, to fulfil the European demand for the supply of Aboriginal bodies, which were treated as commodities. The program looks at shifts in museum policy and the efforts by groups such as the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to have these remains repatriated from overseas institutions back to Australia for proper burial by their descendants.

results.title: Darrow = Clarence Darrow: attorney for the damned
results.creator_credit: John David Coles, Stephen Stept, Richard Heus, Heus-Stept Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description: Born in 1857 in Ohio, Clarence Darrow was to become one of the most famous and highly recognised lawyers in America, most notably through the defence of Eugene Debs during the Pullman railroad strike (1894), the Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb murder trial (1924) and the John Scopes “Monkey trial” (1925). He was a defender and a champion of the poor, an intellect, and a paradox, leaving his successful country practice in Ohio to become a Chicago based lawyer where he entertained and became the darling of the young intellectuals, his Chicago apartment the site for frequent gatherings. In 1907 Darrow successfully defended Bill Haywood and other leaders of the Western Federation of Miners, accused in the bombing-assassination of the former governor of Idaho but in Los Angeles in 1912, it was Darrow himself who was on trial, charged with an attempted bribe of a juror. This made-for-television biographical dramatization of Darrow’s life provides an insight into this brilliant, somewhat unorthodox, lawyer who relied upon the power of the spoken word. Starring Kevin Spacey as Clarence Darrow, with Erin Cressida Wilson, Rebecca Jenkins, Chris Cooper, Paul Klementowicz, Calista Flockhart.

results.title: Operavox
results.creator_credit: Graham Ralph, Barry Purves, Valeri Oganov, Gary Hurst, Natalia Dabizha, Mario Cavalli, Naomi Jones, Sue Goffe, John Cary, Renat Zinnurov, Glenn C. Holberton, Pizzaz Pictures, Christmas Film, BBC-TV, BBC Enterprises, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Bare Boards Production
results.brief_description: This television series from the United Kingdom combines traditional opera with various animation techniques. Contains six segments from the operas: Carmen, Barber of Seville, Turandot, Magic Flute, Rigoletto, Das Rheingold. Traditional puppet animation (by Natalia Dabizha) is used for the Barber of Seville (Rossini) applying a suitably comic tone to the excerpt. Mario Cavalli utilises live action footage, and then paints over the images for his animated segment from Carmen (Bizet). For Rigoletto (Verdi) the dark themes of the opera are ably evoked with stop action puppet animation by Barry J.C. Purves. Other animators include: Gary Hurst (Puccini’s Turandot), Valeri Oganov (Mozart’s The Magic Flute), and Graham Ralph (Wagner’s Das Rheingold). The musical performance is by the Welsh National Opera and features various singers in each segment. Barber of Seville: Donald Maxwell, Peter Bronder, Patricia Bardon (singers), Gareth Jones (conductor) ; Das Rheingold: Phillip Joll, Penelope Walker, Janice Watson (singers), David Seaman (conductor) ; Carmen: Jean Rigby, Adrian Thompson, Donald Maxwell (singers), Julian Smith (conductor) ; Turandot: Jane Eaglen, Edmund Barham, Janet Watson (singers), Wyn Davies (conductor) ; Rigletto: Jonathan Summers, Rosemary Joshua, Anthony Mee (singers), Wyn Davis (musical director) ; The Magic flute: Neill Archer, Alwyn Mellor, John Connell (singers), David Seaman (conductor). Some images of nudity and violence make this DVD unsuitable for young children.
